bibl.title: Letter from Henry Hanson to Henry Rose Carter, January 3, 1923

div1.p: Hanson requests Carter's advice regarding the yellow fever campaign in Peru.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Hanson to Henry Rose Carter, January 3, 1923
div1.opener:
DIRECCION DE LA CAMPAÑA SANITARIA
CONTRA LA FIEBRE AMARILLA
EN EL PERU
---
OFICINA CENTRAL
____
M.
Hanson
3014 Winfield Ave., Baltimore, Md.
January 3,1923.
My dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
The talk which I have been asked to give on the
yellow fever campaign in Peru will probably come off on the 22nd of this
month, as that is the date suggested by the Secretary of the Johns Hopkins
Hospital Medical Society, in the Medical Amphitheatre, the regular meeting
place of the society.

Now the object of this preamble is to ask if you wish to make any
suggestion in regard to the nature of the talk, or indicate any special
feature which you think ought to be especially brought out. In a way the
subject is so big that I scarcely know what to include or exclude. I have
been working on a sort of an outline draft for the general report which I
hope some day to finish and probably publish in its entirety. It would have
to be in a phamphlet if published in full on the plans of my present rough
draft, which is a sort of preleiminary of ideas and recollections of the
work. What I have consists of forty-two pages, eleven of which are single
space, and much of what I have jotted down is more on the order of a memo
which ought to be elaborated to some extent. Other parts no doubts ought to
be cut out. If I did this Dr. Alva's report ought to be translated and in-
cluded as a part of the general report. I have just read it carefully and
I think it very good.

I shall probably give a talk of a different nature before Dr. Freeman's
class, as he has asked me to do so. Dr. Rose sent me the big map which I believe
will help considerably in that it will be a graphic presentation of the geogra-
phy of the coast and enable the listeners to follow the sequence of events.

Would you, before the Medical Society, touch on the diagnosis, medical
aspects and pathology as we found it in the Peruvian work?

In regard to my work here I am still working on the diphtheria problem
which I started, and it is big enough to take up all my time, but I must put in
as much time as possible on the surgical pathology and clinical laboratory diag-
nosis during the few remaining weeks.

I saw Malley (who was in Nicuaragua) today but have not had much chance to
talk to him yet. I knew him some years ago before I went to Panama.
I trust that you are progressing satisfactorily with your Y.F. history.
With best wishes from us all to “you all”
